front: The number of drones you can fly simultaneously.
The maximum height you can fly AGL or above a taller building within a 400-foot radius.
The lightest drone that must be registered.
The time that must pass since you have had alcohol.
The maximum time you can take to file an FAA accident report.
The time you have to notify the FAA if you move.
The lead time required when requesting an FAA waiver
Time that must pass after a final narcotics conviction.
The youngest person who can register a drone.
How long this certification is good for.
The twilight time before sunrise or after sunset when you can still fly.
The distance your anti-collision lights must be visible from when flying during twilight. Also the minimum visibility you must have while flying.
Minimum number of feet below a cloud you must fly.
Minimum number of feet horizontally from a cloud you must fly.
The repair cost of accident damage that requires you to report an accident to the FAA
The "serious injury" AIS level that requires you to file an accident report.
The MULTICOM frequency for self-announce procedures.
The distance you should operate from a tower to avoid hitting guy wires.
Occurs when the wing exceeds its critical angle of attack.
Supposed to be defined in the Pilot's Operating Handbook or UAS Flight Manual
back: but those don't exist for drones.,Center of Gravity (CG) Limits.

front: Determines when the craft stalls. This doesn't change if the vehicle weight changes.
This is the answer to any question about who is responsible.
Aircraft always turn left when circling a runway
back: because drivers sit on the left side of the car in the US, and pilots sit on the left of the plane, too. It's easier for them to look out the left window to see the tower.,Left
even though most drones can't be user-repaired and don't provide a schedule.,Maintenance schedule.

front: Helps to prevent an accident chain.
Doing something without thinking about it.
Thinking accidents won't happen to you.
What's the use? They don't control their destiny.
Nobody can tell me what to do.
should integrate it into all phases of the operation.
That's how you should scan for traffic-let your eyes rest in different areas for a while
back: rather than continuously scanning.,Systematically focus on different segments of the sky for short intervals.

front: is the long way around the planet (the Earth is fat cuz it spins).
is for pilots to talk to each other when there's no tower.
is a base station that broadcasts to pilots when there's no tower.
is used as the CTAF when there's no CTAF (122.9 or 122.95).
Warm air on top of cold air. Fog
back: haze, low clouds, poor visibility, but smooth air.,Temperature inversion
poor visibility, and steady (not showery) precipitation (because stable air is usually humid).,Stable air

front: Just means "high altitude". Air is thinner
back: so lift is decreased.,High density altitude.

front: compass heading (180). The last two #s are the wind speed (04).
Compass headings are always relative to true North in print
Sky is overcast at 700 feet. Remember
(Common Traffic Advisory Frequency) is marked with a C
mark VR checkpoints which mean more planes might be there.
Measure minutes between latitude and longitude degrees. Each tick is one minute. Bigger ticks mark 5 minutes.
Must get ATC (Air Traffic Control) authorization for class B

back: 000 feet to 60,000 feet, all over the US.,Class A airspace

front: Surrounding airports with a control tower
back: radar, and over a specific amount of traffic. Usually 5 NM (nautical mile) radius from 0-4,000 feet, and a 10 NM radius from 1,200-4,000 feet.,Class C airspace

front: Surrounding airports with a control tower. 0-2
back: 500 feet, no specific radius, just shaped around flight patterns. Outside control tower hours, Class D airspace is Class G.,Class D airspace
200 feet and goes up to 18,000 feet.,Class E airspace

front: Places like Camp David and the White House.

back: but if you fly here, it could be dangerous. The government might be testing artillery or missiles or UFOs.,Restricted Areas (R-###)
from NM outward from the US coast. It's cool to fly there it's just not really managed by the US.,Warning Areas (W-###)

front: MOAs consist of airspace with defined limits established for the purpose of separating certain military training activities from IFR traffic. Whenever an MOA is being used
back: nonparticipating IFR traffic may be cleared through an MOA if IFR separation can be provided by ATC. Otherwise, ATC reroutes or restricts nonparticipating IFR traffic.,Military Operations Areas (MOAs)

front: Depicted on aeronautical charts with an "A" followed by a number (e.g.
211) to inform nonparticipating pilots of areas that may contain a high volume of pilot training or an unusual type of aerial activity. Think skydiving training facility
Numbers (like 41/12) are written in 100s of feet above sea level (MSL). So
Automatic Terminal Information System (a loop of useful information broadcast over the radio near an airport)

back: enroute communications, search-and-rescue services, help lost aircraft, etc.,FSS

front: to announce aircraft when there's no ATC.
you need to be wearing a badge.
Universal Communications. A radio broadcast that tells you about non- flight services
back: such as fuel, taxis, and car rentals.,UNICOM
K then three letter airport code

automatic made report by a weather station
heavy thunderstorm and rain showers and mist
